content: I have solved this, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Thanks for the fun puzzle. I vote to approve.

Nice puzzle however there is a spelling mistake in the description. 

"minimum number of die rolls"

should be:

"minimum number of dice rolls" 

Just thought I'd bring it to your attention BlitzProg ;)

Approved.

Though I *would* like it better if the remaining LEFT/RIGHT/UP/DOWN were converted to NORTH/SOUTH/EAST/WEST as well, for consistency, as they can serve for position as well as direction, and the meaning is sound.

(but I CBA to update both your code and mine)
Are you sure Rossi is not a pink chibi pony? ;)

Solved.

* the remaining LEFT/RIGHT/UP/DOWN: a slight hindrance
* the dice index instead of coordinates: a bigger hindrance

* the search space being small enough I can omit serious prunes from my graph search and still make it: well, I suppose that's ok.

[ * JBM not being able to write a fsckn' DFS without messing up the queue: a major hindrance ]

I'll have a few edit proposals now I'm sure I understood the thing. (and I'll go watch the video) I'll get back to it over the weekend.

Yeah, cool puzzle!
Edited, so now you have to write the ID of the dice you move rather than the coordinates.
I have made several small changes to the problem description to correct grammar and improve readability.

Clarified the statement. Rossi's own moves are removed and now implied, for clarity (so only the dices that were moved matter)

Please try to not google Devil Dice before you fully understand the statement ;)

(Might as well change up left down right by north west south east for dice faces a bit later. This will require some more changes to the test cases, though.)
Devil dice! I used to love this game on the original PS, back in my college days. Five-player wars were pretty crazy.

I knew I couldn't be the only one who loved that game :)
I wish we could have a multiplayer game with similar rules.

It's going to be harder and harder for me to have first impressions on this, but here's where I'm at post-update:

* IRON dice. They're the ones who make the problem statement wrong in multiple places.
Problem 1: their first mention is "you can't move them". They ought to be mentioned for existence before.
Problem 2: The second sentence of the first paragraph. (but don't change it yet, see discussion below)
Problem 3: "Rossi's position is always over the last dice he moved"

My suggestion: write (well, leave) the statement as if IRON dice didn't exist. Split all exceptions they introduce into a separate section "IRON dice" that only applies for the latest test cases (I think that's already the case). That would be, if I'm not mistaken: existence; can't move, are always 6; group and walk over same as the other; jumping into the void is not allowed.
Rationale: much easier to explain in the beginning without strictly true convoluted sentences.

Minor stuff:

* I'd rather let some english native confirm (player_one, hello?), but AFAIK *die* is singular, *dice* is plural, *dices* is not an english word^Wnoun.

* Moving dice around section: you ought to repeat the basic movement there near the beginning (the current first item is a consequence of that)

Thanks you!
Also changed dice faces to North South East and West for input (input only)

Considering replacing coordinates of output by dice number. Could make the output more readable and make it clear which dice you're moving.

The code edit on my side for dice index instead of coordinates was very minor. The edit is done so you quickly understand from the test case which dice are being / need to be moved :)

The small search space is intentional, the puzzle is "hard" on it's own to justify all of the simplifying. But I have ideas for much harder versions...
I wish. Picture of Rossi: http://game.lk/Image/covers/bombastic/bombastic-image257614.jpg

I am not sure this is a mistake: die is the irregular plural of dice. In that case, as a non-native speaker (and french for the handicap) I do not know if dice is singular or plural since we are talking about a minimum number. 

However there is couple occurences of a misuse of dice (for example: "If there is a free grid space from Rossi's standing position on a die, he can roll the die there. " which is a clear singular case). 
I do not trust my english skills enough to edit the document.
Oh, I never knew that die was an irregular plural. In that case i think it should be okay in that context.
Yes, nevertheless there are couple "dice" and "die" errors in the text.

Never mind the fact that was all the previous discussion.

If you spot a mistake, name it in the comments; but remember player_one (native) has already cross-checked it.
Doesn't mean I can't make a mistake. :-) I have just finished another reread, though, and I don't see any errors. I am about to give the final approval.

OK. It was based on my understanding of die and dice. If I am not mistaken, dice is plural and die is singular. I thought the following sentence would be worng (but I am not native):

"the minimum number of die rolls." <- plural, dice should be correct.
"you only need to track that face on each die." <- plural, dice should be correct.
"The shortest possible solution to the puzzle - a list of the die rolls" <- there is not only one single die that rossi can roll, so I thought this would be plural too:  dice

"die rolls" -> The confusion comes here by the fact that this is a compound noun. When forming the plural of a compound noun, only the most significant noun is made plural. All other nouns remain in singular form. In this case, "roll" is the most significant noun, so it becomes "rolls", while "die" remains singular. See: https://www.englishclub.com/grammar/nouns-compound-plural.htm

"on each die" -> The noun after the word "each" is always singular, unless part of a prepositional phrase. In that case, it would look like "on each of the dice". See: http://forum.wordreference.com/threads/each-singular-plural.1731766

I understand your confusion. :-)
Hey, thanks for clearing that up. I learned something by the way of it. :)

I understand the will for debuggability.
I'll just make the case for coordinates so people don't think I'm arguing just for the sake of it, but you can keep it as you like, it makes just as much sense.

Why I liked it better with only coordinates is that it enabled me to keep state in a very simple datastructure (an 4x4 array of empty/NEWSTDI), whereas now I've got to either keep track of which die is where externally, or embed the information in the array, but there it messes up with equivalent state merging (it doesn't matter which of these two dice came into a position as long as they're oriented the same).

Oh well.

But really, why didn't I upvote this already?
Done.
I think that would be nice for debugging, and it would be easier to understand what's expected.

Could we consider having the dice rolling directions be NSEW as well? (seems to me they're isomorphic enough to face orientation)

No strong opinions wrt die number vs coordinates; I'm implementing it right now, I'll let you know.

I wasn't aware of the die/dice/dices stuff the whole time. My life is a lice

I have changed the statement according to what you said.

* I'd rather let some english native confirm (player_one, hello?), but AFAIK *die* is singular, *dice* is plural, *dices* is not an english word^Wnoun.

You are correct on all counts, though to be fair, many English natives get this wrong, so it's not surprising that you didn't know.

Counterpoint: I didn't play (or know) it, and I've been pretty confused before I read the statement three times. A more precice description of the mechanics could be in order.

Example ambiguities:

* "simply walk over it" from context I expect that to mean "change die he's on" instead of "step over and end up on the other side", but it's hardly "simply".

* having both UP/DOWN and TOP/BOTTOM. May I suggest going for E/W/N/S instead?

* "shortest solution" but what *is* a solution? Intro says "connect up and show 6", but doesn't really define connectedness.

Seems interesting. How would multiplayer have worked with that?

> Seems interesting. How would multiplayer have worked with that?

Matching up numbers would "damage" your opponents. The larger the set matched, the more damage inflicted. This is a pretty good video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sNPPMwCGmg

You're not the first to say the rules are confusing, however since I grinded the game and its sequel for years, it's hard to see myself what is difficult to understand. I appreciate any input on that subject and will try my best to change the description to make it more clear :)

Also, yes - My goal is to explain without linking to a youtube video or image, since I don't think it is possible. but that would help a lot...

I can draft a rewording if you'll just confirm:

* connectedness: by die side only, no diagonals, right?

* iron dice: I suppose they mean Rossi can possibly not be able to move in all directions anymore when he's on top, only in directions with something to walk on?
Yes to both. Rewrote some parts of the statements, I hope it is clearer. :)
